Er, that sent prematurely. From that link: "For the last few months, Asana has moved from writing Lunascript for our application code to Javascript. The two main things that were slowing down our development: too much remaining research-level work to make the compiler output more performant code; lack of tool support"
I still can't hack css very well in chrome
No argument there. The styling functionality in Chrome is more difficult to get used to, but it's just as capable. It's just more finicky.

I do like the idea of Asana. All of the tools I've looked at to do similar things suck. I'd love to try theirs, but Mochi isn't really suitable, we're too big and there are enough people that refuse to use Facebook (Richard) or can't use Facebook (China) that make it not an option
I'm sure that Javascript errors are easier to debug on the server then the client
and doesn't OKCupid write a lot of their code in C++?  Worked for them.
They actually abandoned lunascript. From http://www.quora.com/Why-is-Asana-developing-their-own-programming-language-(Lunascript):
javascript isn't much better.
firebug. I don't know how I would do front-end work without it.
it's the only reason I keep firefox installed
Chrome's gotten a lot better for debugging front-end stuff. I haven't missed Firebug in months.
does Asana really depend on Facebook?

I didn't see anything in the demo or any of the stuff I've read that said it *required* Facebook to use it. I do think that you can use it without a Facebook login. I would think most companies would want Asana to have its own login system without Facebook. I'm not in the beta, but my guess is that it'd be a problem for a lot of people if it required Facebook.
@mko that's what I thought...
@bob: i don't see a lot of corporate IT departments willing to hand over identity management to Facebook

When I filled out the beta application a couple months ago it asked a lot of questions about if requiring Facebook Connect was acceptable or not. Maybe they had to build out their own identity as well based on the results of that... I don't have recent knowledge of what their product requires
though employees sometimes do it anyway via email and networks
though I don't know how many companies actually have facebook networks, it's possible to have such a thing
http://www.quora.com/What-is-Asanas-Luna-technology-framework

We have catered lunches twice a week at UA - they're amazing. Lunch breaks go from a vague four hour period where any random person might be out of the office to 30 minutes for the entire company all at once.
(also they're delicious)
the start up I was at (before acquisition) did lunches MWF. pretty solid.
Mochi Media does two lunches a week, it's pretty awesome
we also pay for your conferences!
At least, I liked it
yes, indeed :)
I'm assuming you guys have already signed up here, right? https://spreadsheets4.google.com/viewform?hl=en&formkey=dHlTTkUtQmNiZVdjMU5rOGdrWXJONnc6MQ&ndplr=1#gid=0
how can i become a beta user?
@carlhaacke I'm curious too

I signed up.  Re: lunascript, I thought they said they only spent 20% of their time on it.  Re: facebook logon, I inferred from the Beta application that they currently use Facebook Connect as the auth mechanism during beta.  Anyway this looks interesting.
the only thing I worry about is whether they truly understand how nuanced and specialized each business vertical tends to be and trying to fit to all their contexts is difficult
massively ambitious and they seem to have the patience to try pulling this of
to me it feels like a combo of: Wave (real-time feel) + Twitter (async assign for tasks) + FB (overall layout)  + Intentional Software (one model, multiple representations).
